title: PHOTOS: First look inside DS+R's completed V&A East Storehouse
author: Alexander Walter
excerpt: Ever dreamt of wandering through the vast collections of a major museum in its rawest presentation — the storage warehouse? London's new V&A East Storehouse destination attempts to offer visitors an akin experience when it officially opens this Saturday, May 31st. Photo: Hufton+Crow...
text: anchor Photo: Hufton+Crow, courtesy V&A Ever dreamt of wandering through the vast collections of a major museum in its rawest presentation — the storage warehouse? London's new V&A East Storehouse destination attempts to offer visitors an akin experience when it officially opens this Saturday, May 31st. Photo: Hufton+Crow, courtesy V&ADesigned by Diller Scofidio + Renfro, the facility is both a working store and public attraction, built to house over 250,000 objects, 350,000 books, and 1,000 archives in a four-story building that spans over 173,000 square feet. Photo: Hufton+Crow, courtesy V&AThe collection includes works from an eclectic range of disciplines and time periods, from ancient Egyptian footwear through medieval art to Mid-Century furniture and contemporary avant-garde fashion items.  Photo: Hufton+Crow, courtesy V&ASix large-scale objects will be on display for the first time after spending decades in the hidden kind of storage, such as Frank Lloyd Wright's unique 1930s Kaufmann Office interior, a full-scale 20th-century Margarete Schütte-Lihotzky-designed Frankfurt Kitchen, a three-story building section from former east London Robin Hood Gardens residential estate and now demolished brutalist icon, as well as Picasso's monumental Ballets Russes Le Train Bleu theater stage cloth (his largest work worldwide). Photo: Hufton+Crow, courtesy V&A"To celebrate the heterogeneity of the V&A’s collection of collections — spanning a broad variety of mediums, scales, and historical periods — visitors will experience a sense of being immersed in a vast Cabinet of Curiosities," shared DS+R founding partner Elizabeth Diller.  Photo: Hufton+Crow, courtesy V&A"The Collections Hall invites visitors to explore pre-curated works surrounding them, not according to conventional curatorial logics or standard storage taxonomies but guided instead by their own curiosities," Diller continued. "It has been a joy to work with the V&A’s curators and conservators in creating this new kind of institution: Neither warehouse nor museum but rather a hybrid shared by staff and the public with expanded opportunities for access and exchange." Photo: Hufton+Crow, courtesy V&ALocal architects Austin-Smith:Lord collaborated with DS+R on the project, which is set to be the museum's first of two new cultural destinations to open in East London (the new V&A East Museum is expected to swing its doors open in early 2026). Photo: Hufton+Crow, courtesy V&AA preview of the V&A East Storehouse was also presented at the recently opened Venice Architecture Biennale earlier this month.
html:
• anchor

    Photo: Hufton+Crow, courtesy V&A

    Ever dreamt of wandering through the vast collections of a major museum in its rawest presentation — the storage warehouse? London's new V&A East Storehouse destination attempts to offer visitors an akin experience when it officially opens this Saturday, May 31st.

    Designed by Diller Scofidio + Renfro, the facility is both a working store and public attraction, built to house over 250,000 objects, 350,000 books, and 1,000 archives in a four-story building that spans over 173,000 square feet.

    The collection includes works from an eclectic range of disciplines and time periods, from ancient Egyptian footwear through medieval art to Mid-Century furniture and contemporary avant-garde fashion items. 

    Six large-scale objects will be on display for the first time after spending decades in the hidden kind of storage, such as Frank Lloyd Wright's unique 1930s Kaufmann Office interior, a full-scale 20th-century Margarete Schütte-Lihotzky-designed Frankfurt Kitchen, a three-story building section from former east London Robin Hood Gardens residential estate and now demolished brutalist icon, as well as Picasso's monumental Ballets Russes Le Train Bleu theater stage cloth (his largest work worldwide).

    "To celebrate the heterogeneity of the V&A’s collection of collections — spanning a broad variety of mediums, scales, and historical periods — visitors will experience a sense of being immersed in a vast Cabinet of Curiosities," shared DS+R founding partner Elizabeth Diller. 

    "The Collections Hall invites visitors to explore pre-curated works surrounding them, not according to conventional curatorial logics or standard storage taxonomies but guided instead by their own curiosities," Diller continued. "It has been a joy to work with the V&A’s curators and conservators in creating this new kind of institution: Neither warehouse nor museum but rather a hybrid shared by staff and the public with expanded opportunities for access and exchange."

    Local architects Austin-Smith:Lord collaborated with DS+R on the project, which is set to be the museum's first of two new cultural destinations to open in East London (the new V&A East Museum is expected to swing its doors open in early 2026).

    A preview of the V&A East Storehouse was also presented at the recently opened Venice Architecture Biennale earlier this month.
